content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Observation that includes a screenshot of a webpage and some texts. This screenshot will feature Numerical Labels placed in the TOP LEFT corner of each Web Element.
Carefully analyze the visual information to identify the Numerical Label corresponding to the Web Element that requires interaction, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the numerical labels in the TOP LEFT corner of each rectangle (element). Ensure you don't mix them up with other numbers (e.g. Calendar) on the page.
4) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
5) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}
Confidence: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating your confidence level in the action. A higher value means greater confidence.}
Completion: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating how much of the task has been completed until now. Zero means no progress has been made and one means full completion.}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {A labeled screenshot Given by User}

Now given a task: Give the final angle and final length after 6s of a Spring pendulum with spring equilibrium length=0.12m, initial length=0.24m, initial angle=80deg, mass=1kg, spring constant=120 N/m .  Please interact with https://www.wolframalpha.com/ and get the answer.Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I need to input the spring pendulum problem into the search box to get the required calculation. The textbox for input is labeled [6].
Action: Type [6]; Spring pendulum, equilibrium length 0.12m, initial length 0.24m, initial angle 80 degrees, mass 1kg, spring constant 120 N/m, find angle and length after 6 seconds
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.2
token: : Type [6]; Spring pendulum, equilibrium length 0.12m, initial length 0.24m, initial angle 80 degrees, mass 1kg, spring constant 120 N/m, find angle and length after 6 seconds

content: Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: WolframAlpha did not understand the previous query, likely due to complex phrasing. I should try a shorter and simpler input, focusing on the essential physics terms and values.
Action: Type [7]; spring pendulum k=120 N/m, m=1 kg, initial length 0.24 m, equilibrium length 0.12 m, initial angle 80 degrees, position after 6 seconds
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.25
token: : Type [7]; spring pendulum k=120 N/m, m=1 kg, initial length 0.24 m, equilibrium length 0.12 m, initial angle 80 degrees, position after 6 seconds

content: Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: WolframAlpha still doesn't understand the query, possibly because the spring pendulum is a complex physical system requiring differential equation solving. I should simplify even further or rephrase to explicitly ask for solving the equations of motion for a spring pendulum with given initial conditions.
Action: Type [7]; solve spring pendulum equations, k=120 N/m, mass=1 kg, initial length 0.24 m, equilibrium length 0.12 m, initial angle 80 degrees, after 6 seconds
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.3
token: : Type [7]; solve spring pendulum equations, k=120 N/m, mass=1 kg, initial length 0.24 m, equilibrium length 0.12 m, initial angle 80 degrees, after 6 seconds

content: Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The query is now being interpreted as "spring pendulum equations," which suggests WolframAlpha has recognized the topic. The response is still loading and I do not see the final results yet. I should wait for the computation to finish.
Action: Wait
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.4
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The screen is still showing the same loading/interpreting state and hasn’t progressed to the results or computations section. The computation process likely needs more time to complete.
Action: Wait
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.4
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The output still shows the same "Interpreting as: spring pendulum equations" message, indicating no new results or further progress. The page may need more time to compute, or the scroll may be necessary to view more content if results have been generated below the visible area.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.45
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The computational input fields have appeared for manual input of variables, but the fields currently display incorrect values (e.g., spring constant 100 N/m, initial angle 55°). I need to update them with the correct values from the task (spring constant 120 N/m, initial angle 80°, etc.).
Action: Type [0]; 120
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.5
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I've already updated the spring constant input to the correct value. Now I need to update the other computational inputs with the correct values from the task (spring equilibrium length 0.12 m, initial angle 80°, initial length 0.24 m, mass 1 kg, time 6 s). However, this screenshot has returned to the top section; I need to continue with setting computational inputs.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.97
Completion: 0.55
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The spring constant field has been updated correctly (120), but the other fields (spring equilibrium length, initial angle, initial length) still have the wrong values. Next, I need to update the spring equilibrium length to 0.12.
Action: Type [1]; 0.12
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.6
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The screenshot has returned to the top of the page, away from the computational input section. To continue updating the inputs (initial angle, initial length, etc.), I need to scroll back down to the input fields.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.6
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Now the spring constant and spring equilibrium length have been set correctly. The initial angle (should be 80°) and initial length (should be 0.24m) still need updating. The next field to update is the initial angle from vertical to 80.
Action: Type [2]; 80
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.65
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The screenshot is now back at the top, away from the computational input section where further updates are needed. To continue setting the required initial length, I need to return to the computational input fields.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.68

Note that <textarea> or <input> may be textbox, but not exactly. Please focus more on the screenshot and then refer to the textual information.

content:
Thought: The values for spring constant, equilibrium length, and initial angle are now correct. The initial length (should be 0.24 instead of 1) still needs to be updated in the input field [3].
Action: Type [3]; 0.24
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.75

Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.77
